bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 8, 1875

div1.p: Reed assures Emilie Lawrence of his devotion. He describes a visit to New York City to buy her wedding ring.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 8, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
Aug. 8th, 75.

div1.p:
To write
a letter, to-day, that will be
so much as readable, will
require, I fear, more of an
effort than I am capable
of. Imagine a clouded sky --
a heavy mist covering the
whole face of nature -- a
damp atmosphere which
almost chokes you, when
inspired -- add to this a
high temperature and an
entire absence of any
breeze, and you will have
formed an approximative idea
of the weather at Willet's Point.
It is such weather as subtracts
ever from our frail frames
every spark of electricity, and
leaves both mental & physical
fibre completely relaxed.
Notwithstanding this depression,
I have no idea of neglecting my
semi-weekly epistle to the dea-
rest, sweetest & best loved
woman on earth! Exclaim as
you please, & summon
Charles, if you like, but
my opinion will remain
as unalterable as before.
I only wish that this letter
could reach you, before
you receive my attempt
at “rhyming”- For really,
my darling, I'm ashamed of
that production- I don't know
to what to attribute my peer-
less obtuseness, but I as-
sure you, that during the
whole time I was writing,
there was a mist that be-
clouding my mental hori-
zon which I could neither
shake off nor penetrate.
Do what I would, the Muse
was obstinately perverse,
nor would she so much as
shake one dew-drop from
her plumage. Had it not
been owing to my deter-
mination to avoid longer
disappointing you, I should
have annihilated that
epistle, & waited at some
future day, the divine
inspiration. In sending it,
I could not but feel an in-
tense sympathy for the in-
dividual (in this instance, the
Sweetest, loveliest woman
on earth:) who was compelled
to read it. There was but
one consolation; that wasit,
would afford you material
for criticism for many days
to come, & you know, my pre-
cious E., that I much prefer
your criticism to the praise
of all the combined spheres.
Here let me say, that no man
could write such a sentence
as the above, unless he was
desperately infatuated with
some lady- At the same time,
please remember that I am
the man who wrote it, & you -- the lady!
More than this, I felt a restraint
in writing rhyme, especially at
certains stages of my letter-
How could I rhythmically
answer your caustic rem-
arks concerning my departure.
I know that you did not mean
what you said- “No reluct-
ance” in leaving? Emilie dear,
I am more than surprised-
I might ask: Did you show any emotion?
But, never mind, when I next
leave you, there will be
no occasion for such a
remark; for I will show you
an unmistakable signs of my
emotion and devotion.

I again visited New York City
yesterday -- Started early in
the morning & had a very
delightful trip down the
Sound in the Government
Steamer- I first went
to Fort Wood, Bedloe's Island,
to visit Dr Torney- Our re-
union was very warm, &
I was asked many ques-
tions about Miss Emilie.
After lunch, we went to the
city on board a Steam-
Yacht which took us swift-
ly over the waters of the
Bay. My object in going to
the city, among other things,
was to get that all im-
portant ring, which is to
join our hands forever-
After visiting several stores,
I concluded to write & get
the measure of your finger
before purchasing- I thought,
at first, that a ring that
would fit my little finger
loosely would just fit your
ring finger, but I am so
afraid that I might send
one too large, that I prefer
to have you send the exact
measurement of your finger,
& then there can be no 'mis-
take- I enclose a piece of silver
wire which you can use for the
purpose- Take the size of your
finger & cut off the remainder
of the wire with a pair of
scissors. Be sure to enclose
the right piece of wire in your
letter & send it when you
next write. Did the no.s of
the Art Journal arrive?
You must not hesitate to let
me know of any delay that
may occur. Tell Mrs. Dr
Lawrence that I had a
“Spelling bee,” a few eve-
nings ago- “The most skilful gan-
ger I ever knew,” etc was the
subject of amusement- The
gentlemen who did the spel-
ling were Dr Byrne & Lieu-
tenant Lymons; the latter
gentleman graduated at the
head of his class at West
Point, 2 years ago- Dr Byrne
missed 34 & Mr. Lymons 31-
Tell Mrs. L. that I don't think we
have much to be ashamed of
as yet. (I wander how many Miss
E.B.L. missed!) Remember me very
kindly to all who dwell under
the same roof with you. And
remembering that I am ex-
pecting a very sweet letter
from you, to-morrow, believe
me,
div1.closer:
Now & ever, your
affectionate & devoted Walter.
